messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Questions on 2 tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Jim - Dr. Torigoye s Kansho-ki is a favorite book of mine! Lots of wonderful tsuba, many early. Later, I hope to post a photo of a wonderful worm eaten
messages.messageBody:
Jim -

Dr. Torigoye's Kansho-ki is a favorite book of mine! Lots of wonderful tsuba, many early.

Later, I hope to post a photo of a wonderful "worm eaten" ko-kinko tsuba I've had for probably 30 years. Never put through a shinsa, but exciting treatment and technique.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, August 01, 2004 8:42 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Questions on 2 tsuba


Matt,
The two most concentrated sources on the subject that I can think of are:

"Tosogu no Kigen" by Sasano Masayuki, Nichibo Shuppansha, 1979

and

"Uchigatana Koshirae," Tokyo National Museum, 1987

They're primarily in Japanese, but both have some information in English and plenty of illustrations. They also seem to be available on the market these days. A lot of the process is in looking carefully at the examples for yourself and seeing how the pieces fit together. There are bits of information scattered among other books.

Jim



Jim, thanks. Great explanation. Can you recommend a particular book (or
books) that deals with these early tsuba at length? Preferably one with
English text and lots of pictures :-)

Matt

messages.subject: tsuba update
messages.msgSnippet: gang, a while back, I bought a tanto with full koshirae ( minus the koz but thanks to one listeros, i found a match ). The tsuba is that of a dragon ascending
messages.messageBody:
gang,
a while back, I bought a tanto with full koshirae ( minus the koz but
thanks to one listeros, i found a match ).

The tsuba is that of a dragon ascending mt. Fuji.
After failing the magnet test, we determined it is of copper alloy (
shakudo ? ) to simulate iron.

I was looking at the Compton collection.............lo und behold I
found an almost identical design tsuba with the exception of the
tsuba shape + mei ( mine is mumei ) .
If you have the Compton Christie's auction catalog, it's item # 179 (
volume 1 ) page 74-75.
The dragon is identical, the cloud+ Mt. Fuji is almost identical.
Compton's is listed as a Yanagawa school ( signed Yanagawa Naoharu
Isen Noobushu ). The reverse also shows a Mt. Fuji in reflection.

Just thought you all may be interested to know..........

p.s. Gorby, figure out the school of that sukashi tsuba yet ?

milt

> Matt,
> The eccentric proportions and shape of the ana and the small seppa dai
aren't unusual for Muromachi period guards of this type (if it is a
legitimate one). I don't know about that seller so I can't comment about
his stuff. If this is a cast iron copy it probably is modern. A lot of the
modern Chinese fakes do get the proportions all wrong, so it's a matter of
learning about early sword mountings.
>
> Many early "katana-type" mountings had saya and tsuka that were much
thinner than what became the convention during and after the Edo period.
Hence the seppa dai (sized to match the saya and tsuka) are small. The
early kozuka and kogai were often very thin, so the ana made to match them
are narrow. They were sometimes mounted at angles slightly off from the
later 9:00, 3:00 standard. Also at times it was the fashion to mount rather
small guards on large blades, leaving behind nakago-ana that look
disproportionately large.
>
> Of course guards from these early mountings are pretty rare, so chances
are that some misshapen thing on ebay is just a modern fake.
>
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Questions on 2 tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, Too bad that it isn t.  I suppose it s possible that someone could carve a kagamishi-style guard from iron.  The Edo period Shoami did make some guards
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
Too bad that it isn't. I suppose it's possible that someone could carve a kagamishi-style guard from iron. The Edo period Shoami did make some guards that were carved to imitate natural old-style workings of the plate. But the large, irregular nakago-ana sure looks like what you find on old soft metal tsuba. It's worth studying it carefully to be sure that it isn't something legit and very unusual, even though I think that's a long shot.

Anyone seen another "iron Kagamishi" like this? (Not from the inventory of bad feedback ebay sellers.)
Jim


Jim/Matt:

Thanks very much for the info!

The "worm eaten" tsuba is iron....... :(
(I wish it was soft metal)

Thanks again,
Ron


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Questions on 2 tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, The eccentric proportions and shape of the ana and the small seppa dai aren t unusual for Muromachi period guards of this type (if it is a legitimate
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
The eccentric proportions and shape of the ana and the small seppa dai aren't unusual for Muromachi period guards of this type (if it is a legitimate one). I don't know about that seller so I can't comment about his stuff. If this is a cast iron copy it probably is modern. A lot of the modern Chinese fakes do get the proportions all wrong, so it's a matter of learning about early sword mountings.

Many early "katana-type" mountings had saya and tsuka that were much thinner than what became the convention during and after the Edo period. Hence the seppa dai (sized to match the saya and tsuka) are small. The early kozuka and kogai were often very thin, so the ana made to match them are narrow. They were sometimes mounted at angles slightly off from the later 9:00, 3:00 standard. Also at times it was the fashion to mount rather small guards on large blades, leaving behind nakago-ana that look disproportionately large.

Of course guards from these early mountings are pretty rare, so chances are that some misshapen thing on ebay is just a modern fake.

Jim



Ron that second tsuba reminds me of some of the stuff being sold on ebay by
the guy who used to call himself 'mrvtjun', I think he changed his handle to
'po-edo' now or something.
I always thought that quite a few of his tsuba looked funky with strangely
proportioned nakago and hitsu ana. Alot of them do not have a proper seppa
dai either. Anyway judging from that dudes feedback alot of them are cheap
modern fakes. He gets LOTS of negatives :-) The rest are low quality 20th
century renditions with some original and papered pieces mixed in.

Could this be such a modern piece also?


Matt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

generation people. "Owari to Mikawa no Tsubako" specifically
outlines the work of four Yamakichi generations and then identifies
this type as later work. I have seen this type of guard receive a
kanteisho, but they are not held in the same regard as early
Yamakichibei tsuba.
>
> What is the other guard made out of? I have seen Kagamishi tsuba
with that "worm eaten" design. I haven't specifically seen it
combined with mon like that, but I have seen the worm eaten rim
combined with other motifs. So, not unusual if it is done in a
copper-based alloy with a dark patina.
>
> The photos make it look like an iron guard, and if it is then that
is something I haven't seen before. In that case I would guess that
it's a cast taken from a Kagamishi tsuba.
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Questions on 2 tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, That decoration around the hitsuana is a trait of one of the late generation people.   Owari to Mikawa no Tsubako specifically outlines the work of four
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
That decoration around the hitsuana is a trait of one of the late generation people. "Owari to Mikawa no Tsubako" specifically outlines the work of four Yamakichi generations and then identifies this type as later work. I have seen this type of guard receive a kanteisho, but they are not held in the same regard as early Yamakichibei tsuba.

What is the other guard made out of? I have seen Kagamishi tsuba with that "worm eaten" design. I haven't specifically seen it combined with mon like that, but I have seen the worm eaten rim combined with other motifs. So, not unusual if it is done in a copper-based alloy with a dark patina.

The photos make it look like an iron guard, and if it is then that is something I haven't seen before. In that case I would guess that it's a cast taken from a Kagamishi tsuba.
Jim



Dear Listeros:

I was wondering if you could help me out on these 2 tsuba.

First is Yamakichibei:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Yamak1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Yamak2.jpg
Note that the plate looks old, old traces of lacquer and the tsuba
is of 3 plate construction (two thin outer layers and a thicker core-
you can see it in the hitsui ana).
Which generation?

Second I have never seen a tsuba like this:
http://www.nihontophile.com/Shoami1.jpg
http://www.nihontophile.com/Shoami2.jpg
Which school? (Shoami?)

Thanks very much for looking,
Ron
